comments.commentBody: Okay, so I'm an old fogy. But there are some of us out here who have absolutely no interest in The Simpsons. None. De nada! Nor P. Diddy by any of his names, nor either Ure whoever they are, nor the Mouse person. Thank goodness for Ava Gardner giving an easy entry into the bottom right, and Seiji Ozawa in the mid-left. But the upper left was locked up tighter than Christmas for way, way too long, because of, what to me, was obscurity crossing obscurity (YTTRIA x MOE SYZSLAK, primarily), alongside some long misdirections (BASKET CASE and AFTERTASTE). And then, I WANTA BE SEDATED...well, now I do, but, nope, never heard of it. I finally scraped and scrapped my way through, and it seems to be right best I can tell. But, whew! Much too obscure to be very much fun, for this old fogy anyway. I guess some of us are just sore losers!

Martin,

Thanks for the somewhat refresher on EMF. I'm an EE (Masters, even), but it was a long time ago that I was in school. EMF was a somewhat esoteric thing; we engineers quickly went to volts & amps - you know, the real thing. So I really had no idea what the symbol for EMF was.

For purposes of the puzzle, epsilon became clear early on.

And thanks also for the little write-up on "inurn" (a new word for me).

It's nice to see that Posters #36 & #37 weren't stuck inside yesterday!

-- jpgaskell

PS I have my magnifying glass out trying to see what letters I'm typing right now!

I actualy finished another Friday puzzle ... hm! Not too bad. I was surprised at the measure zero clue -- rather specialized, that one. However ... three nits, or carps, if you will:

(1) Being inurned is being placed in an urn, not buried. That's what it means, and I refuse to acknowledge OED solipsism.

(2) In my scholarly and professional career, lower case epsilon took on basically two meanings: in Physics it was the symbol for the dielectric constant of materials and the vacuum, and in Maths it was the symbol for a quantity that was made to approach zero in a limiting process. The symbol for the electromotive force was always a battery or a capital letter E, script or otherwise. (If you want to call it Capital Epsilon, fine, but that's quibbling.)

(3) An asymmetrical grid is not an optical illusion, or even delusion. It looks like an asymmetrical grid, period. I don't see any way you can color the squares in a 15 x 15 grid and come up with a true optical illusion -- the "resolution" is way too coarse. (Now, if you were allowed to tilt the four grid lines around each square, you can make up some doozies .... nah.)

A good and happy long weekend to all.
Can we, maybe, expand upon what rf says in 12.?  Let's make that,  with a capital C, "the City."

Marcia is the San Francisco of the Brady Family.  Jan is the Oakland, and Cindy is the San Jose.  Greg is the Walnut Creek, Peter is the Berkeley, and Bobby is the El Cerrito.  Mr. Brady is the San Rafael and Carol is the Napa.  Cousin Oliver is the Modesto.  Think about it, it makes sense.

Its an intangible. I was born in 'the city' and consider that to be a badge of honor. Spent a Lot of time there. Saw the Beatles there. Went to the zoo a lot. Fondly remember the Fun House. The Haight. The Fillmore. Sam Wo's.
Why this attraction and feeling of comfort? I can't explain it. I'm not especially jingoistic; though I was similarly proud to live in Catalunya for 5 years.
I've not done a lot of comparing of other places such as this article discusses. Though, recently I visited Lisbon, felt that vibe and thought of the City. They have a nice, old tram system very reminiscent of the SF cable cars. I think its a combination of geography and culture...
What I do know is its certainly a good feeling to experience.

I remember when the Warriors first moved to town, and their singlets just said "The City"!

On a personal note, I've often said that Angra do Heroismo, Terceira, is "the San Francisco of the Azores."

First of all, nobody even knows where San Jose begins and ends. Even when you're driving around Silicon Valley, it's hard to know whether you're in San Jose or not. So it's no surprise that "the San Jose of" is pitiful (a mere 179K hits).

But "the Silicon Valley of" is a winner (6.5M hits). Calling Bangalore the Silicon Valley of India even has its own Wikipedia entry. And did you know that Zhongguancun is the Silicon Valley of China? Or Zelenograd in Russia? Couldn't find any hits for the Silicon Valley of Kyrgyzstan though...
I actually think it's the other way around. San Francisco is the Rio de Janeiro of the US as much as it is the Cape Town of the US.

Dude #5 I likes your comment.
Seattle and Vancouver (the Canadian one...) are a better version of a Western coastal city where chaos looms. I love SF but it is only SF, and as it is like no city, no city is like it.

If you like to find comparable places though, I can say after spending some time all over Asia:
Singapore is definitely NOT the SF of Asia, even though they would probably like to be. That would be Jogyakarta on Java (not Yakarta, different city but same island).
Hell what a great place! Coastal city, ancient temples as good as in Kyoto, great mix of new and old cultures, great food, same chaos as SF, great art scene, and above all towering is Mt Merapi, one of the most dangerous volcanoes there is. Love the place as much as SF.

While the geography of San Francisco is spectacular, the city is a little over-rated. Much of the housing (with some exceptions) is bland and rundown, it and surrounding area are choked with traffic, public transportation is mediocre, and it is incredibly cold and foggy. For families it is very expensive with lousy public schools overall. For an urban environment, NY is far more diverse and interesting. I guess the appeal of SF is that one can both enjoy a lively city environment and be able to go mountain biking easily as well.

My firstborn was conceived there but grew up in Maine, which tops my list of best places of ever to live, although San Francisco is a close second.  Now he lives in San Francisco while I am solidly planted in Maine, my native state.  I'd love to live in SF for at least part of the year but my average income doesn't allow it.  Earlier, psnewman commented that "SF can't sustain an environment for 'real people' earning real wages."  This is San Francisco's dilemma: its real world foundation keeps slipping, and it's nothing to do with the seven fault lines under the city.
I've often said that San Francisco is Brooklyn without a Manhattan.  Makes me think of what Brooklyn might be like without it's connection to its wealthy next door neighbor.

When it comes to the Napa Valley, the situation is a bit more complex. Napa Valley is often called, "the Provence of the United States," or, "the Tuscany of America." At the same time, Napa Valley is used to describe other wine growing regions. Thus, Stellenbosch is known as "the Napa Valley of South Africa," Mendoza is "the Napa Valley of Argentina," and the Hudson Valley is "the Napa Valley of the East." And Napa Valley may also be used to describe the center of other food producers. Denver is, "the Napa Valley of beer," and Vermont is called, "the Napa Valley of cheese." Although not every comparison may be quite so welcome; Beaver, Oklahoma has been called, "the Napa Valley of cow chips."

It's true that San Francisco is "the City" for so many of us, and it's not out of competition with anywhere else; it's just that the archetype of that idea seems to be here, wherever else it may be as well.

It's not a metropolis, a New York, London, or Tokyo; it's a polis, a city, as Florence was (population of, what, 40,000 during most of the 15th & 16th centuries??), as Athens was (same idea, and the original archetype of that idea); and so on.

Who, now, takes seriously a "city" with a population of only some 600,000?? Well, anyone who has tried to bulldoze Nancy Pelosi, for one, or Phil Burton for another; but I digress.

Or maybe I don't. We know who we like here, and we support them, exactly because they don't just support who we like, or even are like; a polis is in a certain way a large and inevitably messy family (I repeat myself), nonetheless ferociously loyal to some shared sense of what that family is; and I do think that's completely true of San Francisco.

We don't just support gay rights, or whatever the current public flashpoint is; we support the general right to human dignity, and we genuinely savor, not just tolerate, diversity; it's the most important social pleasure of this city; and I think that's why this particular city is, at least in that respect, the archetype of what a city should be.
Let's not let Vancouver, B.C., get mixed up in this!
Okay, San Francisco is great, but most people who claim San Francisco as their "City" live in its periphery.

Sorry I don't have time to read all 250+ other comments to see if this has already been said, but the obvious mistake made by the young lady was her major.  Religious and women studies are probably fun subjects, but they are basically useless in the real world, and now she is paying the price.  I wonder why this wasn't mentioned by the reporter.  Perhaps it was left out because the blame for the poor choice lands squarely on the individual and can't be sloughed off onto an institution.
Re: #244.  A lot of schools were caught, and maybe still are, getting kickbacks from banks for steering students towards the most expensive student loan options.

I forgot to mention the other government programs Wall Street suckles to this day.  CDOs were invented to disperse that oil slick of debt after the S&L Crisis, but that dispersent operates as common practice, now.  And CDSs were invented to help manage the Russian Debt Crisis.  and we know how ubiquitous those are.  Kind of like those mysterious layers of oil particles and other chemicals drifting below the surface of an already destabalized ocean.  That what you get for a public education.

After spending two years at arguably the best state school in Florida, I felt stifled and transferred to Columbia University in New York for a year to participate in a study abroad program. I knew from the first week of school I could never again be happy at my school and I applied to transfer.

Though I was offered some amount of scholarship funding, I still had to take out around $30,000 a year to afford the tuition and and living expenses (my divorced parents split the bill for my $700/month Chinatown apartment). I believe I owe well over $100,000 at this point, but I'm too scared to open the statements until I can afford to make payments.

Unlike Cortney, however, I would never, EVER, "happily give up" my time spent at Columbia. Those were some of the best, most formative years of my life. I believe it is also in large part due to my degree from Columbia that I was accepted to a number of graduate programs in my senior year. I am now pursuing a PhD in French at NYU.

How will I pay off those loans? Well, it is my hope that if I work hard and write a solid dissertation, I will end up with a decent position at a college or university and a salary high enough to afford the monthly payments. As for whether or not Columbia should have told me I was in "deep doo doo" - well, I worked hard to be there and I would not have listened. Not to counselors, not to my parents. Sorry, but I worked hard to get myself to Columbia and I felt special every time I set foot in a classroom or library; it was not an option to walk away for not being rich.

I am confident that some day I will be debt-free, and after that point please believe I will be donating whatever I can to help students in the same position as I once was. As for where to place the blame, I don't consider myself in need of "blame," though I take responsibility. It would also be nice if the government could cut us some more slack somewhere, be it with interest rates or tax cuts.

Well.... I had a similar major (Cultural Studies with a concentration in Philosophy (Continental) and Sociology (Women's Studies track))... but from a small state school where I incurred less than $20,000 debt. I lived at home, worked two part-time jobs, had several scholarships, but still could not afford the tuition. I also have a single mom who was financially incapable of paying for my education. Yes, I was accepted at Smith College but chose not to attend because I knew I could not afford it. But my education was invaluable and I do not regret studying a degree that is not marketable.
What am I doing now? The economy sucks, I work part time as a home health aide while I'm in graduate school deferring student loan debt and gaining more education and job skills. I hope to study Occupational Therapy next year, and when I graduate with a second MS degree I will have a decent enough salary to make a living and repay my debt. I plan to take advantage of the IRB and to work with older adults or children with disabilities in order to minimize the years I have to repay (10 years, or 120 payments, versus some protracted repayment plans).
There are options out there, but you have to search for them. Being 24 years old, I’m not too worried – yet. But I know I won’t be able to afford a home, let alone children, in several years. That is a sacrifice I am willing to make because (and perhaps this is selfishness on my part) I’d rather feel fulfilled as a person and feel that I am assisting those in society who desperately need help than trying to make a million dollars in the financial sector by screwing over other people. The meek shall inherit the earth? That is something that Ms. Munna and I could both discuss eternally – and probably with a great deal more intelligence, compassion, and thoughtfulness than those contributing such harsh, judgmental ‘advice’. Thank you.

Ron Lieber, Ms. Munna and dozens commentators with your personal stories on this blog:
I salute each and every one of you from bottom of my heart! Because at this very moment,
there are millions incoming college students, current university students and their parents
doing exactly the same thing Ms. Munna and her mother did. It is my hope your collective
effort would wake them up and ask some questions: Is many aspects of US higher education
system a gigantic scam? Can America employers absorb more than one million college graduates following degrees each and every year: English, Psychology, Political Science, History, international relations and of course women studies? How many college graduates
live with their parents for years without stable jobs? And how many college graduates
have to settle to occupations don't require college degrees at all?

Back in the 1970's, I emerged from college with less than $1000. in student loan indebtedness. It still took me nearly a decade to pay it off. A changing economy, a poor choice in majors (I was counting on a resurgence in the space program) and my conscious decision to do something else with my life all "conspired" to leave me underemployed and frequently unemployed. Now, more than three decades later, I have still not found employment because of my college education, but rather through networking, self-taught skills and initiative.
My personal experiences have taught me to avoid debt and my recommendation to the younger generation is to proceed only with caution. There are too few guarantees in life, and education in itself will likely not secure economic rewards. Rather, seek out higher education for self-development and not for the financial success it may or may not bring.

This writer completely misses the point. This is all about moral hazard. The reason why the banks don't care whether you can pay your loan back is because the government says you can't charge off student loans. They are basically the best kind of debt to invest in. We need to change this law. If you can charge off student loans in bankruptcy then the loan amounts will be much smaller and they will look at the student's ability to repay. If you give someone the ability to borrow unlimited amounts of money, they will always take it. Same with the colleges. Within the next 10 years many will begin applying for debt restructuring because no one will be dumb enough to pay their insane tuitions.
